awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Atmospheric Mixed Phase Chemistry for Improved Climate Predictions: Field Measurements and Modeling of the Southern Oxidant and Aerosol Study
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will investigate processes associated with the natural emissions of biogenic volatile organic compounds (BVOCs) that lead to the formation of secondary organic aerosol (SOA). Of particular interest is the assessment of organic compounds derived from BVOC oxidation that are water-soluble, CCN-active and react readily with the OH radical in controlled laboratory experiments to create low-volatility products that may form secondary aerosol via multiphase organic chemistry. Continuous measurements of SOA chemical and physical properties will be made during the Southern Oxidant and Aerosol Study (SOAS) to be conducted near Centreville Alabama in the summer of 2013. This study will focus on the role of particle phase liquid water and particle pH in determining SOA mass. The data will be analyzed to elucidate the linkages between bio- and anthropogenic emissions on multiphase chemistry, and estimate the magnitude of the contribution of multiphase pathways to SOA.

This research is needed in order to improve understanding of local and global climate and air quality. The results may help explain whether the anomalous temperature trend in the Southeast, which has not warmed like other regions in response to global climate change, is due to interactions among biogenic and anthropogenic emissions that can affect regional climate through formation of secondary organic aerosol. During the field campaign, there will be many activities supporting science communication and education.

por.por_cntn:
Two major findings resulted from this study, each significant on their own, however, combined they illustrate the complex nature of atmospheric chemical responses to changing emissions and highlight the significance of these research findings.

First, we investigated the formation of secondary organic aerosol (SOA) in the southeastern US, a location where these aerosol species account for a large fraction of the overall aerosol mass. We focused on how anthropogenic pollutants from human activities control aerosol formation from biogenic volatile organic compounds emitted by vegetation. Our research (Xu et al., 2015) has provided direct observational evidence showing that SOA formed from biogenic isoprene and monoterpenes is greatly modulated by anthropogenic SO2 and NOx emissions, respectively. This means that pollution controls that lead to reductions in SO2 and NOx emissions can result in a double benefit; PM2.5 mass concentrations decrease due to the direct reduction in the resulting aerosol, sulfate from SO2 and nitrate from NOx, plus the added benefit of additional reductions in organic aerosol from biogenic VOCs, since these are formed through atmospheric processes strongly linked to SO2 and NOx concentrations (Xu et al., 2015).

Focusing on the role of SO2, and hence sulfate, our studies showed high correlations between sulfate aerosol and isprene SOA. We found that this was largely due to sulfate-enhancement of particle surface area leading to higher uptake of isoprene oxidation products. Particle acidity (pH) was also thought to play a critical role in the isoprene SOA-sulfate linkage; the aerosol must have a sufficiently low pH for the conversion of isoprene to organic aerosol to occur (Xu et al., 2015). Our research, however, showed that the fine aerosol pH was so low that pH was not rate limiting in the process.

The second major finding of our research focused on addressing the question of what will happen to aerosol pH as SO2, and hence sulfate aerosol, is continuously reduced due to emission controls.  This research showed that despite substantial SO2 reductions in the past 15 years, there was significant change aerosol pH. That is, the particles did not becoming more neutral, but instead remain highly acidic with pH of 0 to 2, despite significant decreases in sulfate, the species that mainly drives particle pH (Weber et al., 2016). This surprising result has a number of significant policy implications. In a general sense it means the acidity-related health and climate benefits, widely anticipated from sulfur reductions are unlikely to occur until atmospheric sulfate concentrations reach near pre-anthropogenic levels (Weber et al., 2016). In terms of isoprene SOA formation, it means that the isoprene conversion to organic aerosol process will remain the same, even with SO2 dropping to very low levels. 

Another broad impact of our finding of a constant low aerosol pH is that it overthrows a widely held view in the atmospheric chemistry community; that as SO2 emissions drop and the aerosol is assumed to become more neutral, semi-volatile acidic species will begin to partition to the aerosol, taking the place of the sulfate. For example, it is thought that SO2 reductions will not be as beneficial as expected because the semi volatile nitrate (from NOx) will simply replace sulfate aeroso. Our work shows that because the aerosol will remain highly acidic, this will not happen.

Thus, reductions in SO2 and NOx will have a substantial effect on reducing PM2.5 concentrations; concentrations of both sulfate and organic aerosol from biogenic emissions should drop, and nitrate will not replace the decreasing sulfate. It is important to understand these processes since PM2.5 aerosol has substantial impacts on climate, air quality, and human health.

In addition to our direct research results noted above, the data generated by this project has been utilized by other researchers to characterize fine particles, investigate how they change after emission, and how they impact air quality in the southeastern US, contributing to 13 publications on these various aspects.
